text.text:
You should probably do more stuff - learn new skills, take on new experiences, meet new people - but you don't because you're a big fat 'fraidy cat. We get it, it's hard, but there are institutions out there looking to help. 

It's universally accepted that there are two things that make the acquiring of new abilities more convenient: workshops and alcohol. Getting together with like-minded self improvers and listening to a professional tell you how to improve a skill whilst you glug from a semi-chilled bottle of Echo Falls is a fail-safe path to success - it's actually how Michael Phelps got into swimming.

tip.text:
They call this place an 'art gym for the creative muscles' and we quite like that - especially when this gym isn't frequented by mirror-obsessed 'roiders listening to David Guetta through leaky headphones but friendly, helpful souls ready to aid you on your first painted pot. This arty workshop is pretty adult-orientated - you won't find too many kids here, just curious sorts aided by a welcome BYOB policy, enthusiastically embracing a whole new skill.

They put on a range of different workshops which are all suited for beginners including handmade pottery, homemade earrings, painted ceramics, t-shirt design and calligraphy. The sessions aren't overbooked either so you'll get all the attention and help you need with those two left hands of yours.

text.text: M.Y.O are the standard bearers for adult-oriented workshops. With an outpost in Borough and one in Peckham Levels, their classes cover everything from ceramics and earring making to calligraphy and wreath making. Plus their drinking policy is at the heart of what they do: less, 'get it down ya, fresher,' and more, 'we're grown ups who like to paint clay and sip Â£8 pinot noir'.

tip.text:
We tip our hats to London Cookery School for being the first to grab that name - that's a SEO hit if ever we saw one. From the outside, this school doesn't look like the kind of place you'd want your future kids attending, but it's what's on the inside that counts - and we rate this as an excellent place to learn how to cook something tasty from far flung shores.

They do three hour classes here from a range of cuisines including Colombian, Italian, Korean and Nepalese. But the stars of the show are no doubt the sushi and dim sum-making classes. Goddamn Londoners are crazy for that stuff. The instructors are very patient, knowledgeable and friendly and will put you right at ease as you manipulate that food into something resembling the real deal. Classes are around Â£45 which is not bad value at all.

text.text: The London Cookery School runs a range of international cooking classes mostly of an Asian persuasion, and their sushi and dim sum classes, led by knowledgeable and patient pros, are the most popular. BYOB is an optional Â£3, but any cookery school that lets you drink whilst playing with knives is pretty rad in our book.

listing.name: Earl of East - Candle Making Workshops
listing.subtitle: Wax On, Wax Off

tip.text: Light it up at Earl of East's candle making workshops where you'll learn how to make a bougie flammable wax stick for you or someone you like a lot. Sniff out the perfect blend of fragrance and essential oils, then wax it all up, let it set overnight, and take it home the next day. You're literally conquering #hygge, you are an unstoppable lifestyle fairy.

text.text: Lock down some of that coveted hygge at this beginners candle-making workshop in London Fields. Choose your favourite stank and covert it to wax form before taking it home and putting it above the toilet in the shared bathroom as a clear signal to your disgusting housemates. BYOB and fire can be dangerous, so only drink if you can candle it ð¥.

tip.text:
Anyone yearning for yarn should shimmy on down to this weaving studio asap, where drop-in classes run the gamut of fabric-based creative outputs for all levels of expertise. Tapestry weaving, pompom earring making, embroidery and sashiko stitching are just some of the more obscure classes they run.

It's a relaxed, wholesome and fun environment where classes have been known to start with a shot of tequilla and BYOB is allowed. Come learn to weave your way to ultimate textile goals and prepare your relatives for an onslaught of woven gifts come Christmas time.

text.text: Anyone yearning for yarn should shimmy on down to this weaving studio asap, where drop-in classes run the gamut of fabric-based activities for all levels of expertise. Tapestry weaving, pompom earring making, embroidery and sashiko stitching are just some of the more obscure classes they run. It's a relaxed, fun environment where classes have been known to start with a shot of tequila and BYOB is allowed.

tip.text:
Holed up in a shipping container next to 40 Ft Brewery, The Dusty Knuckle is a social enterprise Bakery serving up freshly baked sourdough, knockout sandwiches (weekdays only), sweet pastries and some quality Ozone coffee.

On a sunny day their bench seating is the perfect place to munch on your mortadella, sweet and sour baby onions, aged parmesan and fresh rocket focaccia, sitting amongst the shipping containers, feeling just about as hip as you can feel. Luckily there's a few seats inside too so you can grab a quick lunch no matter the weather; or just order from the little hatch and run along home with your goods safely tucked away under that blue workman's jacket of yours.

They also run all sorts of workshops if you're looking to get in on that baking action at home.

text.text: This ethically minded East London bakery has been pumping out delicious bakes AND opportunities for struggling young'uns for years now. But they also offer bread-making classes if you're looking to get in on that baking action at home. This one isn't technically BYOB, but they have free beers on hand from their neighbour, 40ft Brewery, which we're going to allow because it's for a good cause dammit.

tip.text:
Firstly, give yourself a bit of credit for managing to keep yourself fed and watered. Well done you. Now let's see how far you can extend that responsibility and build a terrarium! A terrarium is like a mini-garden in a jar, and Jar & Fern put on super social, very fun workshops in the South London area that take newbies through all the steps of creating this pocket of eden.

They have a range of different workshops that'll give you all you require to create your own which you can then take home at the end of the sesh. Tickets don't come cheap, but for a special occasion/gift/activity to try something completely different, this looks pretty soothing. Check their website for event details.

text.text: A terrarium is like a mini-garden in a jar, and Jar & Fern put on super social, very fun workshops in the South London area that take newbies through all the steps of creating this pocket of eden. If you attend a class at their studio, it's BYOB - at a pub, maybe not.

tip.text:
Hackney Wick's life drawing class is a nice way to let those creative juices flow into something tangible after work. They run two classes: one on Monday at People's Park Tavern; the other on Wednesday at Stour Space and the deal is simple. You draw models who are sometimes naked, sometimes not, for a short while.

It's open to all levels, BYOB and guidance is offered too - our one tip would be to not look at the work of the person next to you, because we're pretty sure professional artists go to these things to build up their confidence. And who can blame them?

text.text: This life drawing class is a nice way to let those creative juices flow into something tangible after work. They run two classes: one on Monday at People's Park Tavern; the other on Wednesday at Stour Space and the deal is simple. You draw models who are sometimes naked, sometimes not, for a short while. It's open to all levels, BYOB and they have people more talented than you on hand if you're struggling.

tip.text:
So you think you can Warhol? Well, he used silk screening techniques, so that's irrelevant. But if you want to learn to screen print, get it popping at Print Club's beginners workshop, where you'll learn the basics and make your own work of art to adorn your sad, white walls - or you can gift your masterpiece to your biggest fan.

The staff are verified print wizards and will walk you through the whole process, from Photoshopping your design, transferring it from acetate to your screen, exposing it in the UV canon, and finally printing it in your colour of choice. All materials are provided for and high quality, you just need to bring a design - anything form a photo of your mam to something you've knocked up digitally - and a little creativity (and patience, it's an all day affair).

text.text: This all-day intensive class on the ins and outs of screen printing will take you from the design process, all the way through aligning, acetate blasting, printing and drying. At the end, you'll have a stack of handmade prints destined for the walls of your unsuspecting extended family. It's a tea and biscuit vibe in the morning but as soon as it hits 12 there's no shame in popping to the offie at the end of the road.

tip.text:
If you've ever cast a glance at a stuffed animal and wanted to stuff your very own, then this is the thing for you. These anthropomorphic and naturalist taxidermy workshops will show you the skills of basic taxidermy: how to skin, prep, preserve, mount and position an animal in either a natural pose or doing something a human would.

The class isn't for the faint of heart, and blood and gore could well make an appearance. They also say don't bring any dead animals to the class with you - so we'll reluctantly put our plans for our flatmates' pet hamster to bed. For now. Classes range from Â£35-180 depending on the animal you're stuffing, and include a delicious vegetarian (thank god) lunch.

text.text: These taxidermy workshops will show you the skills of basic taxidermy: how to skin, prep, preserve, mount and position an animal in either a natural pose or doing something a human would. Classes range from Â£35-180 depending on the animal you're stuffing, and include a delicious vegetarian (thank god) lunch after the skinning. Not expressly BYOB but they're OK with people drinking if it helps them process the gore.
